messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 53 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Why we couldn’t prove SETH hardness of the Closest Vector Problem for even norms!

Paper Abstract: Abstract Recent work [BGS17, ABGS21] has shown 𝖲𝖤𝖳𝖧𝖲𝖤𝖳𝖧\mathsf{SETH} hardness of 𝖢𝖵𝖯𝖢𝖵𝖯\mathsf{CVP} in the ℓpsubscriptℓ𝑝\ell_{p} norm for any p𝑝p that is not an even integer. This result was shown by giving a Karp reduction from k𝑘k-𝖲𝖠𝖳𝖲𝖠𝖳\mathsf{SAT} on n𝑛n variables to 𝖢𝖵𝖯𝖢𝖵𝖯\mathsf{CVP} on a lattice of rank n𝑛n. In this work, we show a barrier towards proving a similar result for 𝖢𝖵𝖯𝖢𝖵𝖯\mathsf{CVP} in the ℓpsubscriptℓ𝑝\ell_{p} norm where p𝑝p is an even integer. We show that for any c>0𝑐0c>0, if for every k>0𝑘0k>0, there exists an efficient reduction that maps a k𝑘k-𝖲𝖠𝖳𝖲𝖠𝖳\mathsf{SAT} instance on n𝑛n variables to a 𝖢𝖵𝖯𝖢𝖵𝖯\mathsf{CVP} instance for a lattice of rank at most ncsuperscript𝑛𝑐n^{c} in the Euclidean norm, then 𝖼𝗈𝖭𝖯⊂𝖭𝖯/𝖯𝗈𝗅𝗒𝖼𝗈𝖭𝖯𝖭𝖯𝖯𝗈𝗅𝗒\mathsf{coNP}\subset\mathsf{NP}/\mathsf{Poly}. We prove a similar result for 𝖢𝖵𝖯𝖢𝖵𝖯\mathsf{CVP} for all even norms under a mild additional promise that the ratio of the distance of the target from the lattice and the shortest non-zero vector in the lattice is bounded by exp⁡(nO​(1))superscript𝑛𝑂1\exp(n^{O(1)}). Furthermore, we show that for any c>0𝑐0c>0, and any even integer p𝑝p, if for every k>0𝑘0k>0, there exists an efficient reduction that maps a k𝑘k-𝖲𝖠𝖳𝖲𝖠𝖳\mathsf{SAT} instance on n𝑛n variables to a 𝖲𝖵𝖯psubscript𝖲𝖵𝖯𝑝\mathsf{SVP}_{p} instance for a lattice of rank at most ncsuperscript𝑛𝑐n^{c}, then 𝖼𝗈𝖭𝖯⊂𝖭𝖯/𝖯𝗈𝗅𝗒𝖼𝗈𝖭𝖯𝖭𝖯𝖯𝗈𝗅𝗒\mathsf{coNP}\subset\mathsf{NP}/\mathsf{Poly}.111The result for 𝖲𝖵𝖯𝖲𝖵𝖯\mathsf{SVP} does not require any additional promise. While prior results have indicated that lattice problems in the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm (Euclidean norm) are easier than lattice problems in other norms, this is the first result that shows a separation between these problems. We achieve this by using a result by Dell and van Melkebeek [DvM14] on the impossibility of the existence of a reduction that compresses an arbitrary k𝑘k-𝖲𝖠𝖳𝖲𝖠𝖳\mathsf{SAT} instance into a string of length 𝒪​(nk−ε)𝒪superscript𝑛𝑘𝜀\mathcal{O}(n^{k-\varepsilon}) for any ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0. In addition to 𝖢𝖵𝖯𝖢𝖵𝖯\mathsf{CVP}, we also show that the same result holds for the Subset-Sum problem using similar techniques.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 53 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 53"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Lattice problems beyond polynomial time",
        "Fine-grained hardness of CVP(P)- Everything that we can prove (and nothing else)",
        "SETH-based lower bounds for subset sum and bicriteria path",
        "A note on the concrete hardness of the shortest independent vector in lattices",
        "Dimension-preserving reductions between svp and cvp in different p-norms",
        "Solving the Shortest Vector Problem in 2nsuperscript2𝑛2^{n} time via discrete Gaussian sampling",
        "Solving the closest vector problem in 2^ n time–the discrete gaussian strikes again!",
        "Generating hard instances of lattice problems",
        "Improved algorithms for the shortest vector problem and the closest vector problem in the infinity norm",
        "(Gap/S)ETH hardness of SVP",
        "On Lovász’ lattice reduction and the nearest lattice point problem",
        "Dynamic programming",
        "Polynomial formulations as a barrier for reduction-based hardness proofs",
        "On the quantitative hardness of CVP",
        "Hardness of approximation for knapsack problems",
        "Sampling methods for shortest vectors, closest vectors and successive minima",
        "Hardness of Bounded Distance Decoding on Lattices in ℓpsubscriptℓ𝑝\\ell_{p} Norms",
        "Improved hardness of bdd and svp under gap-(s) eth",
        "Breaking iterated knapsacks",
        "Lattice-based FHE as secure as PKE",
        "On problems as hard as cnf-sat",
        "Nondeterministic extensions of the strong exponential time hypothesis and consequences for non-reducibility",
        "A (1/ε2)nsuperscript1superscript𝜀2𝑛(1/\\varepsilon^{2})^{n}-time sieving algorithm for approximate integer programming",
        "Parameterized complexity",
        "Approximating 𝖲𝖵𝖯∞subscript𝖲𝖵𝖯\\mathsf{SVP}_{\\infty} to within almost-polynomial factors is NP-hard",
        "Approximating CVP to within almost-polynomial factors is NP-hard",
        "New limits to classical and quantum instance compression",
        "Satisfiability allows no nontrivial sparsification unless the polynomial-time hierarchy collapses",
        "Approximate CVPpsubscriptCVP𝑝\\mathrm{CVP}_{p} in time 20.802​nsuperscript20.802𝑛2^{0.802\\,n}",
        "Approximate cvpp in time 20.802 n",
        "Infeasibility of instance compression and succinct pcps for np",
        "An application of simultaneous Diophantine approximation in combinatorial optimization",
        "Fully homomorphic encryption using ideal lattices",
        "Approximating shortest lattice vectors is not harder than approximating closest lattice vectors",
        "Invitation to data reduction and problem kernelization",
        "On the compressibility of NP instances and cryptographic applications",
        "Computing partitions with applications to the knapsack problem",
        "On the complexity of k-sat",
        "Bounding the running time of algorithms for scheduling and packing problems",
        "Minkowski’s convex body theorem and integer programming",
        "The Prime Number Theorem",
        "Factoring polynomials with rational coefficients",
        "Solving low-density subset sum problems",
        "Worst-case to average-case reductions based on Gaussian measures",
        "Lattice-based cryptography",
        "A deterministic single exponential time algorithm for most lattice problems based on Voronoi cell computations",
        "Lattices in computer science, lecture 2, Fall 2004",
        "On lattices, learning with errors, random linear codes, and cryptography",
        "Lattice problems and norm embeddings",
        "A polynomial-time algorithm for breaking the basic Merkle-Hellman cryptosystem",
        "Another np-complete problem and the complexity of computing short vectors in a lattice",
        "Open problems around exact algorithms",
        "Some consequences of non-uniform conditions on uniform classes"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 53 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Why we couldn’t prove SETH hardness of the Closest Vector Problem for even norms!, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
